abstract.para: This manual serves as an entry point for setting up the eID Identity Provider. The target audience is system administrators.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document (in uppercase, as shown) are to be interpreted as described in [RFC2119] .

The eID Identity Provider Service provides a portal which Relying Parties (aka Service Providers) can use to identify/authenticate its users using the eID Applet. This can be done using following authentication protocols:
SAML v2.0 Browser Post/Redirect/Artifact Profile
OpenID v2.0
WS-Federation v1.1
The eID Identity Provider Service also comes with an Admin portal that allows administrators to manage the eID Identity Provider via an easy to use web portal interface. In the following sections we will use $EID_IDP_ADDRESS as the (internal) web address where the eID IdP product has been deployed.

The source code of the eID Identity Provider Service is publicly available and can be found at
eID Identity Provider Source Code
. Please note that the eID IdP has dependencies on the eID Trust Service product, which can be found at
eID Trust Service source code
and on the eID Applet product, which can be found at
eID Applet source code

section.title: Installation
section.para: The eID Identity Provider Service JBoss distribution is based on the eID Trust Service JBoss distribution. This means that all generic eID Trust Service configuration is also applicable to the eID Identity Provider Service. We refer to the eID Trust Service Administrator Manual for all non eID IdP specific configuration aspects.

The eID Identity Provider Service distribution also bundles the eID Trust Service. If you do not want to deploy the eID Trust Service along with the eID Identity Provider Service you can remove the following files from the distribution:
jboss/server/default/deploy/eid-trust-service-deploy-1.0.0-SNAPSHOT.ear
jboss/server/all/deploy/eid-trust-service-deploy-1.0.0-SNAPSHOT.ear

section.title: Database
section.para:
The eID Identity Provider Service comes with distributions for the following database products:
MySQL
PostgreSQL
Oracle

section.title: MySQL
section.para: The database initialization is similar to that of the eID Trust Service product. The eID Identity Provider Service specific database initialization script is called eid-idp-ddl-mysql.sql and is located under the sql directory.

section.title: PostgreSQL
section.para: The database initialization is similar to that of the eID Trust Service product. The eID Identity Provider Service specific database initialization script is called eid-idp-ddl-postgresql.sql and is located under the sql directory.

section.title: Oracle
section.para: The database initialization is similar to that of the eID Trust Service product. The eID Identity Provider Service specific database initialization script is called eid-idp-ddl-oracle.sql and is located under the sql directory.

Note that the SQL-DDL script will create a hibernate sequence ( use for generation of entity IDs ) by default. Case your distribution will also run the eID Trust Service this sequence will already be created, causing the script to fail on that one. As this is the last command in the initialization script this does not really matter yet can be confusing. The command is: create sequence hibernate_sequence;

section.title: Deployment
section.para: Deploy the eID Identity Provider Service the same way you deploy the eID Trust Service.

section.title: eID IdP Admin Portal
section.para: The eID Identity Provider Service Administrator Portal is available at $EID_IDP_ADDRESS/eid-idp-admin-portal/ . After deployment of the eID Identity Provider Service you should register an administrator by logging into the admin portal. Additional administrators can be registered by letting them first log into the admin portal. This will result in them being added as pending administrators, ready to be approved by a normal administrator.

In the admin portal you should at least configure the following under PKI Validation :
eID Trust Service XKMS2 URL. For example
https://www.e-contract.be/eid-trust-service-ws/xkms2
eID Trust Service Authentication Trust Domain. For example: BE-AUTH
eID Trust Service Identification (National Registry) Trust Domain. For example: BE-NAT-REG

section.title: eID IdP Service Identity
section.para: The eID IdP should have a service identity configured. This identity will be used to sign outgoing SAML v2.0 responses and the SAML v2.0 assertions embedded in the WS-Federation Security Token. So every authentication protocol that requires to sign the response message will use this service identity. This is important to provide integrity of the assertion/response and authentication of the asserting party being the eID IdP to the SAML Relying Party. How to configure the service identity is documented in the eID Trust Service Admin Manual.

section.title: eID IdP SSL Certificate
section.para: Without configuration of the eID IdP SSL Certificate, authentications performed by the eID Applet will be subject to man-in-the-middle attacks. The TLS server certificate is digested and used in the authentication signature but without specifying the SSL certificate no verification can be done.

section.title: Unique User Identifiers
section.para: You can configure the eID IdP so that each application will receive a unique user identifier that is different from the national registration number. You can configure this globally (i.e. for all applications) or on a per application basis.
Global configuration can be done via "Configuration", "IdP Default Configuration", "Default HMAC-SHA1 identifier secret".
Per application configuration can be done via "Relying Parties", then select/create a relying party. Go to the "Secrets" tab and set a value for "HMAC-SHA1 Identifier Secret".
If you don't configure the HMAC secret, the national registration number will not be hashed.

section.title: eID IdP Core
section.para: The eID Identity Provider Service core is available at: $EID_IDP_ADDRESS/eid-idp/ . This site can handle incoming authentication requests from Relying Parties.

section.title: OpenID and Apache
section.para:
The OpenID XRDS mimetype might be wrong when using recent versions of Apache as front-end web server. This can be fixed by the following Apache config work-around: <Location "/eid-idp/endpoints/openid/ident/xrds"> ForceType application/xrds+xml </Location>
<Location "/eid-idp/endpoints/openid/auth/xrds"> ForceType application/xrds+xml </Location>
<Location "/eid-idp/endpoints/openid/auth-ident/xrds"> ForceType application/xrds+xml </Location>
